messages: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:27): interesting, instead of setting status to "fixed", microsoft set it to "not reproducable" when a bug i've reported has been fixed in ie8b2
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:28): though perhaps that's a good way to get the fix verified by the reporter
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:31): I've had two marked as Fixed
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:31): (and they are actually fixed, I think)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:32): but one Not Reproducible, and I don't think it's actually fixed but maybe my test case was unreliable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:35): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: interesting typo in "how often the local property is within the namespace"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:35): (property is -> properties)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:38): OMG, Microsoft's download site for IE8 popped up an ad for me to install silverlight, even though I still have silverlight installed from when I needed it to watch videos on nbcolympics.com
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:39): lordy, now b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 is suggesting that whatwg.org use a CDN. :-P
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:39): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: fwiw, i think you'd save time by learning those 3 namespace URIs
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:40): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: instead of looking them up
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:40): i never learnt the HTML4 DOCTYPE
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:40): that's the main reason for the HTML5 synax. :-D
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:40): http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml http://www.w3.org/2000/svg http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:40): <!doctype html public "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN">
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:43): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: not a typo. artifact of a different text input method
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:43): I learned all the HTML 4.01 and XHTML 1.0/1.1 DOCTYPEs. It's not that hard, since the follow a common pattern
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:44): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: no, I suggested that only n.whatwg.org be on a CDN

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:44): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: with xmlns dereferencing going on, it seems like a bad idea that W3C isn't separating its ns URIs from the rest on the DNS level
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:44): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, wouldn't that be a costly thing to maintain?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:44): read http://esw.w3.org/topic/HTML/history found http://www.hixie.ch/specs/html/apps/web-apps-1 and realized almost nothing survived
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:45): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Pay for it by embedding adverts

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:45): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yes. the point of what I wrote is to shield people who don't want the Power of RDF from the RDF Tax. However, someone needs to pay for the CDN
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:46): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: so to make the cost entirely borne by the RDF community, you'd need a way to make the RDF community to pay the CDN bill
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): I haven't learden the HTML 4 doctypes either. I always copy them from my doctype page
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:47): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: yeah that was intentional when i minted n.whatwg.org
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:48): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: speech recognition eh? how is it going?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:48): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: needs fixing

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:49): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, adverts on a server intended purely for delivering machine processable data, rather than human consumable data, seems rather ineffective.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:51): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Not at all - you just have to exploit how the machines process that data, so that the adverts get shown to those machines' users
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:51): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: speech recognition is more accurate than Ink, though
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:51): yeah well
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:51): ink sucks :-P

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:51): although I don't particularly like the whole idea, one way to pay for it would be to require software that intends to use it, has to pay licence fees. That way it's paid for by those who use it.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:51): that would work
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:52): we could optimise away actually setting anything up if we did that
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:52): Use Google Cache as a free CDN
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:53): speaking of free CDNs, what pays for Coral?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:53): is NYU bankrolling it out of the goodness of their hearts?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:55): CDN?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:55): Content Distribution Network
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:55): ta

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:56): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I think it's running on PlanetLab, which I think is mostly run by universities, presumably from various sources of research funding
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:57): oh, cool. it works http://lachy.id.au.nyud.net/log/

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:01): "As of January 2006, it receives about 25 million requests per day from more than 1 million unique clients." - that sounds like it's probably only tens of megabytes a second, which isn't particularly extreme
